In[41]:
# CSV  
X, y = [], []

with open("./dataset.csv", "r") as f:
    next(f)
    classes = [-1, 1]
    #print(type(f))
    #print(f)
    for line in f:
        #print(line)
        #print(type(line))
        line = line.strip()
        #print(line)
        if line:
            values = line.split(",")
            #print(type(values))
        else:
            continue
        X.append([float(i) for i in values[:2]])
        #         y.append(int(values[-1])
        y.append(classes[int(values[-1])])

print(len(X), len(y))
#print(np.array(y).shape)
print(y)

import random


#  
random.seed(123)

#   
idx = list(range(len(X)))
random.shuffle(idx)

#  80    20  split
X_train = [X[i] for i in idx[:80]]
y_train = [y[i] for i in idx[:80]]
X_test = [X[i] for i in idx[80:]]
y_test = [y[i] for i in idx[80:]]

1-3) Perceptron model

Perceptron model .

Perceptron model , forward, backward, train, evaluation .

  • __init__ Perceptron weights bias .
  • forward input Perceptron .
  • backward Perceptron gradient .
  • train Perceptron forward backward Perceptron .
  • evaluation input data . (: Accuracy )

# <your code> Perceptron class .

:

  • weights , bias 0 .
  • activation function 0 1, 0 -1 .
  • : Cost Function MSE Cross-Entropy $J(w) = -y(w^Tx)$ . , $x\in Y$

Perceptron

: https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Scheme-of-a-perceptron-A-nonlinear-activation-function-BULLET-is-applied-to-the_fig3_315788933

In[98]:
class Perceptron:
    def __init__(self, num_features, learning_rate=0.1, batch_size=1):
        self.batch_size = batch_size
        self.weights = np.random.rand(
            num_features,
        )
        self.bias = 0
        self.lr = learning_rate

    def shuffle_datasets(self, a, b):
        assert len(a) == len(b)
        p = np.random.permutation(len(a))
        return a[p], b[p]

    #    
    def forward(self, x):
        # np.matmul  weight batched feature linear combination    .
        #  , [ , weight ]   x [weight , 1]   weight
        # linear combination  .
        #  , x weight  np.matmul(x, weight) [ , 1]   linear combination .
        linear_combinations = np.matmul(x,self.weights) + self.bias # <your code>

        # Activation function np.where    .
        # np.where(statement,   statement   ,   statement   )
        pred = np.where(linear_combinations > 0 , 1, -1) # <your code>
        #print(linear_combinations, ", ", pred)
        return pred

    def calc_loss_and_gradient(self, x, pred, label): #  testcase    . 
        #print( x,', ', pred, ', ', label)
        loss = sum([-label*np.matmul(x,self.weights)]) # <your code>
        # Hint :  *    .
        gradient_weight = np.array([label*x[i] for i in range(len(self.weights))]) # <your code>
        gradient_bias = label # <your code> #    
        #print(gradient_weight, ', ', gradient_bias)
        return loss, gradient_weight, gradient_bias

    def update_parameters(self, gradient_weight, gradient_bias):
        self.weights += gradient_weight * self.lr# <your code> # mean . # -- -> + =>  epoch  
        self.bias +=  gradient_bias*self.lr # <your code>

    def calc_accuracy(self, x, y):
        pred = self.forward(x)
        #  True,  False  array 
        correct_predictions = pred == y
        # True  
        counts_true = np.count_nonzero(correct_predictions)
        total_nums = np.size(pred)
        return counts_true / total_nums * 100

    def fit(self, x_train, y_train, epochs):
        x_arr = np.array(x_train)
        y_arr = np.array(y_train)

        # epochs  
        for e in range(epochs):
            x, y = self.shuffle_datasets(x_arr, y_arr)

            #   data 
            num_batches = len(x) // self.batch_size

            # batch size     training example 
            remain = len(x) % self.batch_size

            x = x[remain:]  # remain  training example 
            y = y[remain:]
            x = np.array_split(x, num_batches)  #    
            y = np.array_split(y, num_batches)

            #    
            for batch_x_y in zip(x, y):  #   
                batch_x, batch_y = batch_x_y

                pred = self.forward(batch_x)

                #     ,  True,  False  array 
                wrong_predictions = pred != batch_y
                num_wrong_predictions = np.count_nonzero(wrong_predictions)
                skip_this_batch = num_wrong_predictions == 0

                #print(num_wrong_predictions)

                if skip_this_batch:
                    continue

                #   
                pred = pred[wrong_predictions]
                batch_x = batch_x[wrong_predictions]
                batch_y = batch_y[wrong_predictions]

                
                #print(num_wrong_predictions)

                for i in range(num_wrong_predictions):
                    loss, gradient_weight, gradient_bias = self.calc_loss_and_gradient(
                        batch_x[i], pred[i], batch_y[i]
                    )
                    # parameter update backward pass 
                    self.update_parameters(gradient_weight, gradient_bias)

            #print( self.weights )

            print(
                f"Epoch {e} train accuracy : {self.calc_accuracy(x_train, y_train):.2f}%"
            )
            if self.calc_accuracy(x_train, y_train) == 100:
                print("Stopped training.")
                break

Q. . ( )
forward : linear_combinations pred = np.where(linear_combinations > 0 , 1, -1) . calc_loss_and_gradient :
linear_combinations loss function gradient . update_parameters : parameter update. .

1-4) Perceptron

Perceptron Trainset 5 epoch weight, bias print.

In[99]:
ppn = Perceptron(
    num_features=2, learning_rate=0.1, batch_size=4
)  #   Perceptron  

#print(" : " ,ppn.weights)

ppn.fit(X_train, y_train, 5)  #  5 epoch 

#   weight, bias 
print(ppn.weights)
print(ppn.bias)

Epoch 0 train accuracy : 98.75%
Epoch 1 train accuracy : 100.00%
Stopped training.
[ 0.48006351 -0.21063816]
-1.2

1-5)

Training set Test set accuracy .

In[100]:
# Train dataset  
train_acc = ppn.calc_accuracy(X_train, y_train)
print("Train set accuracy: %.2f%%" % (train_acc))

Train set accuracy: 100.00%
In[101]:
# Test dataset  
test_acc = ppn.calc_accuracy(X_test, y_test)
print("Test set accuracy: %.2f%%" % (test_acc))

Test set accuracy: 100.00%

1-6) Decision Boundary

train test 2 scatter plot .

In[102]:
### Train  Decision Boundary 
#  
plt.scatter(
    [i[0] for idx, i in enumerate(X_train) if y_train[idx] == -1],
    [i[1] for idx, i in enumerate(X_train) if y_train[idx] == -1],
    label="class 0",
    marker="o",
)
plt.scatter(
    [i[0] for idx, i in enumerate(X_train) if y_train[idx] == 1],
    [i[1] for idx, i in enumerate(X_train) if y_train[idx] == 1],
    label="class 1",
    marker="s",
)
# Perscptron Weight Bias  
plt.plot(
    [0, 7],
    [-ppn.bias / ppn.weights[1], -(7 * ppn.weights[0] + ppn.bias) / ppn.weights[1]],
)

#  
plt.title("Training set")
plt.xlabel("feature 1")
plt.ylabel("feature 2")
plt.xlim([0.0, 7])
plt.ylim([-0.8, 0.8])
plt.legend()
plt.show()

### Test  Decision Boundary 
#  
plt.scatter(
    [i[0] for idx, i in enumerate(X_test) if y_test[idx] == -1],
    [i[1] for idx, i in enumerate(X_test) if y_test[idx] == -1],
    label="class 0",
    marker="o",
)

plt.scatter(
    [i[0] for idx, i in enumerate(X_test) if y_test[idx] == 1],
    [i[1] for idx, i in enumerate(X_test) if y_test[idx] == 1],
    label="class 1",
    marker="s",
)
# Perscptron Weight Bias  
plt.plot(
    [0, 7],
    [-ppn.bias / ppn.weights[1], -(7 * ppn.weights[0] + ppn.bias) / ppn.weights[1]],
)

#  
plt.title("Test set")
plt.xlabel("feature 1")
plt.ylabel("feature 2")
plt.xlim([0.0, 7])
plt.ylim([-0.8, 0.8])
plt.legend()
plt.show()

S2. Discussion

1) activation .

[] activation . .

  1. : S 1/1+e^(-as)
  2. : 2 1
  3. ReLU(Rectified Linear Unit) : max(0,s) lower-bound clipping

2) Perceptron .

[] Perceptron decision_boundary decision_boundary . XOR decision_boundary . perceptron .
